content.description: Climb up the easiest climb on the cliff,placing a ton of gear on your way up. This is a great route for new leaders about half way up you can escape off to the left if you get to scared and walk off or rap off the tree.
content.protection: Trad gear up to 2". There is gear after every move. To a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Start in front of an oak tree to left side of the cliff

content.description: A harder variation to Kennel Boy.
content.protection: small wires & draws.  rap from anchors

content.description: Start the same as When Dads Run Free climb up a little then break right on a small rail to a left facing corner. Climb the corner up to an overlap, just before the overlap is the crux short and awkward. Climb over the overlap to the anchor on WDRF.
content.protection: Trad gear the crux is not very well protected.
content.location: Same start as When Dads Run Free.

climbs.name: Stealing Candy from a Baby
climbs.fa: Brad and Ian White and Ian Cruickshank

content.description: Climb up to a left facing corner with a few intresting moves. Climb the corner until you can break right fhrough a weekness in the wall on the right. Then a long reach and up to the anchors on Punk Rock.
content.protection: Trad with funky nut placements the first twenty feet to bolt anchors.
content.location: Start the same as Punk Rock In between Punk Rock and The Sting

content.description: Slightly harder variation to Rock Garden.
content.location: Cimb the face straight up to join Rock Garden. Step right to a groove (5.7) to a blunt arÍte that is climbed straight up to the two-bolt anchor on Fore Paws.

climbs.name: Rock Garden
climbs.fa: Ed Webster and Billy Squier, summer of 1995

content.description: A fun and well-protected crack leading up to a tree anchor (two cords + two quicklinks as of 8/9/2021). Follow the hand-sized crack up into a left-facing corner with good protection along the way. A short chimney section up top will represent the crux for many. The crack will lead you directly to a tree with the anchor. If placing a top rope on Kennel Boy (5.10a just to the left of Rock Garden), there is an obvious bolt climber's left just before the end of Rock Garden that can be easily clipped on the way down and offers an easy directional. A 60M rope is sufficient length for climbs off this anchor.
content.protection: Bring a standard trad rack. There are no bolts or pitons.
content.location: The route starts just to the right of a large, prominent overlap/roof (about seven to ten feet off the ground) by the cliffs left hand side. The crack, corner, and chimney of Rock Garden is very obvious.

content.description:
Start to the left of the big corner. Climb the face to the left of the big corner to reach a small, left-facing corner below the roof. Move right into the main corner and pull the roof. Continue through ledges and up the thin crack above, making a hard mantle up onto the anchor ledge. 

  NOTE: There were Bats in the crack on 7-21-2012. May want to skip the first finger lock/gear placement in the upper crack to check for these guys.
content.location: Starts under the roof to the right of Rock Garden.

climbs.name: Punk Rock
climbs.fa: Brad White, Ian White and Ian Cruickshank (2000)

content.description: Climb a blocky face to get to a comfy little platform at the bottom of an inclined left-facing corner. Layback the crack in the corner (there are also holds on the face to the right), and follow a thin crack traversing right under an overlap (crux). Go up left an easier slab to the anchors.
content.location: Look for the left-facing blocky corner just to the right of the slab at the left end of the crag.

climbs.name: Kennel Boy
climbs.fa: October 1998, Dave Kelly and Robert Sagerman

content.description: A surprisingly nice climb with fun moves on perfect rock. Start by putting  a piece in the small slot above the starting roof. Climb up the corner/arete on the roof's right side to the large ledge above. Then make some unprotected 5.9 face moves up to a fixed pin. A short finger crack above leads to balance moves, a bolt, and the crux. Continue to a tree belay.
content.protection: Bring a small rack with an emphasis on small wires/TCUS to supplement the fixed pin and bolt. Tree anchor on top.
content.location: This route is five feet to the left of Rock Garden and starts under the far right hand side of the prominent roof/overlap seven to ten feet off the ground on the left side of the cliff. Look for a small slot for a wire at the lip, a fixed pin jutting out in the middle of the climb, and a bolt high above on a clean white headwall. To descend, rappel from the tree at the climb's finish.

content.description:
Without the big, vegetated ledge halfway up, this route might be one of the better lines at Lost Horizon. As it is, this is certainly still a worthwhile route with enjoyable climbing. 

  Start under a 10' high roof below an obvious fingercrack splitting the face above. Pull the roof and enjoy nice finger locking up to the ledge. Climb blocky features off the right side of the ledge to a stance at a steep, wide crack (no wide gear necessary). Pull awkwardly over the steepness onto easy slabby terrain and scramble up to a double-bolt anchor with rap rings. There is also a tree with slings about 20' higher at the top of the cliff if you plan on climbing a route at the upper tier.
content.location: Where the approach trail meets the cliff at the more popular routes (Punk Rock, Rock Garden, etc.) walk about 50 yards to the right along the cliff. Incisor Crack is easily identified by a small roof about 10' up and namesake finger crack.
Climb Rock Garden to the a crack on the right. Just to the right of the middle section of Rock Garden look for some thin flakes. Continue up a flake (5.7) to the same ledge and belay as Rock Garden.

content.description: This route has a relatively short crux section consisting of a few moves along a good horizontal then a big dynamic move up to a good flat jug. After the crux the climbing eases a lot as you climb up to a good ledge then up a nice 5.7 flake to another ledge with a bolted anchor. Good rock and well protected but a bit of a one move wonder.
content.protection: Standard rack. Small nuts are helpful for the thin flake section after the crux.
content.location: A few feet to the right of the route Rock Garden. There is a bolt about 20 feet up a few feet above a long horizontal crack.

content.description: Use a flake to pull over the low roof. Make a few moves up the slab, clip a bolt, and then continue up the slab and the difficulty quickly eases. Scramble up easy ground, aiming for the flaring crack above. Awkwardly pull through this (crux, I thought) and then head left to the anchor for Incisor Crack.
content.protection: Single rack up to a #3 C4 will do just fine.
content.location: This is the furthest right route at the Lost Horizon. Look for the bolt about 8 feet above the roof. It's about 10 feet right of the obvious finger crack of Incisor Crack.

content.description: Start just under the left side of the big roof. Climb up to the roof and make a big reach out from under the roof to a nice hand size crack. Then up to the same anchor of Punk Rock.
content.location: Just under the left side of the big roof

content.description: Climb up to the larges part of the roof with a small horn on it. Climb through the roof. If you have a long reach by pass the horn it will set you up better to come over the roof. Themyou have two choices finish up Kennel Boy or a easier path to the anchor of Punk Rock.
content.protection: Trad gear the crux is hard to place.
content.location: Start in the middle of the big roof. Just under the small horn.

content.description: This is a small but very nice little cliff located above and to the left of Sundown's Main Cliff. It hosts a variety of route from 5.4 to 5.11+ and is almost never crowded. It gets a mix of sun and shade and can be a little bit windier than the Main Cliff. The rock quality is excellent although some areas may see seepage.
